Award.AwardTitle: GoAmazon 2014 Contributions of Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds to Organic Aerosol Formation in the Presence and Absence of Anthropogenic Pollution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is focused on elucidating the chemical and physical processes that control the atmospheric oxidation of biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC) in the atmosphere and the subsequent formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA). It is also investigating the influence of anthropogenic pollution on these processes. The project is part of a collaborative field study located in the Amazon region around Manaus, Brazil. NSF previously funded this principal investigator to evaluate the role of BVOC in forming secondary organic aerosol in southern forests in Alabama, as part of the Southern Atmosphere Study (previously named SOAS) in the summer of 2013. The Amazon site is complimentary to the Alabama site, with critical differences. These differences allow this work to be applicable to diverse ecosystems and socio-economic regions. The Alabama site has high aerosol loading and large regional cooling due to aerosols, and the Amazon site has low aerosol loading in a region that is rapidly developing and undergoing substantial land use change leading to increasing anthropogenic emissions.

The project will result in the first chemically speciated in situ measurements in the Amazon of oxidation products from biogenic volatile organic compounds. The effort will contribute to a better understanding of climate change and air quality issues. This project contributes to a larger study, GOAMAZON-2014, funded by the U.S. Department of Energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Green Ocean Amazon (GoAmazon 2014/5) campaign focused on elucidating the role of biogenic volatile organic compound (BVOC) emissions in atmospheric chemistry and climate, and understanding how the transformation and fate of BVOC is altered by the presence of anthropogenic pollution sources. The Amazon forest is the dominant source of BVOCs globally, and is being converted to urban and agricultural uses through land clearing including large scale burning. The 2014 GoAmazon field campaign at the ARM facility at T3 afforded study of chemical transformations in the region downwind of Manaus. Local BVOC emissions are high, and their chemical oxidation can be studied with varying degrees of influence by the urban plume.  Two intensive operating periods took place during Jan-Mar 2014 (wet season) and Aug-Oct 2014 (dry season). Contrasting both seasons allowed study of varying chemical and atmospheric states (i.e. clean, background aerosol with regular rainfall vs higher BVOC emissions and biomass burning with decreased rainfall). This large scale collaborative study was designed to comprehensively examine how BVOC emissions and their interaction with anthropogenic pollution alter the atmosphere’s oxidative capacity, influence secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation, atmospheric composition and, ultimately, affect the earth’s radiation balance and climate.

We made speciated measurements of semivolatile organic matter, including both gas and particle phases, with in-situ hourly observations with our Semi-Volatile Thermal desorption Aerosol Gas chromatograph (SVTAG) instrument. In addition, we collected aerosol samples on quartz filters at 12-hour time resolution (wet season) and 4-hour time resolution (dry season), totaling ~450 samples. The filters were analyzed off-line using a unique instrument in our laboratory (multidimensional GC with both electron impact and vacuum ultraviolet ionization coupled to high mass resolution time-of-flight mass spectrometry (GCxGC/HR-VUV,EI-TOFMS).

These data were examined to assess the factors controlling gas particle partitioning of oxidation products, and the differences in the reaction pathways for SOA formation from BVOC in the presence and absence of anthropogenic influence. We focused most of our analyses on measurements of a suite of chemicals that have previously been identified as major tracers for BVOC oxidation in both polluted and clean environments, and we simultaneously endeavored to dramatically increase the range of chemicals observed and identified. For example, we measured an abundance (as compared to other non-tropical forests) of biogenic compounds known as sesquiterpenes as well as ~50 new oxidation products that originate from their chemistry.  Further, we identified over 30 compounds attributed to biomass burning.    Exchange of atmospheric organic compounds between gas and particle phases is important in the production and chemistry of particulate matter but is poorly understood due to a lack of simultaneous measurements in both phases of individual compounds. Polyols formed from isoprene oxidation contribute 11% (wet season) and 7% (dry season) on average to particle-phase organic mass but are also observed to have substantial gas-phase concentrations contrary to many models that treat these compounds as nonvolatile. The broader results show that the gas-particle partitioning of approximately 100 known and newly observed oxidation products is not well explained by environmental factors (e.g., temperature). Compounds of high- volatility have higher particle fractions than expected from state-of-the-art models. These observations support the conclusion that many commonly measured biogenic oxidation products may be bound in low-volatility mass (e.g., accretion products, inorganic− organic adducts) that remains to be chemically resolved.

The chemical complexity of atmospheric organic aerosol (OA) has caused substantial uncertainties in understanding its origins and environmental impacts. We provide new constraints on OA origins through novel compositional characterization with molecular-level details. Our results suggest that SOA from isoprene oxidation accounts for ~30-50% of wet season OA in Amazonia and sesquiterpenes account for a few percent. We find that both natural and anthropogenic (derived from industrial emissions of sulfur oxides) sulfate plays a central role in determining the mass and type of compounds produced from isoprene.  Measurements during GoAmazon were conducted under levels of sulfate representative of clean and even pre-industrial conditions, and isoprene SOA comprised higher levels of inorganic-organic adducts (organosulfates) than has been observed elsewhere around the world. We infer that under natural conditions in regions with high isoprene emission, preindustrial aerosol sulfate was likely almost exclusively organosulfates derived from isoprene. Because organosulfate and sulfate have very different optical properties this implies preindustrial sulfate may have been less reflective than current climate models assume. These findings elucidate the potential for strong anthropogenic-biogenic interaction affecting ambient aerosol in the Central Amazon, especially as Manaus rapidly develops and grows.  This further points out the importance of reducing anthropogenic emissions, especially under a changing climate, where biogenic emissions will likely keep increasing.

Our work has improved understanding of BVOC emission, oxidation, and particle formation pathways at the molecular level, how these pathways change when influenced by anthropogenic sources, and their importance for the atmospheric budget of aerosols and the earth’s radiation balance on regional scales.
